lines.text: A wagon train come in headin' for California and I'm joinin' up with it.
When?
Sundown.
Well, sundown is a good time to leave. Indians don't hanker much for night fightin'.
Mr. Oury, am I hearing you right? Are you talking about giving Arizona back to the Indians?
That's one way of saying it, Phoebe.
Like Oury says, it's better to leave what we built here than get our bones picked clean by buzzards.
What did you ever build?
Are you asking me to marry you?
Around about. Is there still something you don't like about me?
No, it's not that. If there wasn't something I didn't like about a man, I couldn't stand the sight of him.

Now, the prisoner at the bar, the charge against you is that you up and blowed the head plumb off of Gus Modesko. In consequence of which said shooting said Gus is deader than blazes. Are you guilty or not guilty?
Well, Judge, I don't reckon I could say not guilty when everybody seen me do it.
Now what in tunket made you act like that, Joe?
Drinking. Just drinking.
Well the verdict of this here tribunal is that Joe Briggs is fined five dollars for disturbing the peace. The court is hereby adjourned to Lazarus Ward's Bar where said fine will duly be disposed of.
I figure it sounds crazy to most people... going to California just to see it. But there's a gallivanted bug in my blood and that's the way I am.

Now sometime before morning, I'm going to let off both barrels of this shotgun right at you. I don't know just what time it'll happen... whenever my finger gets to itching too much. But you can depend on it. You're gonna have a double hole blown clear through you. Maybe ten minutes, maybe two hours. All you have to do is sit comfortable until I think it's the right time.
Gosh almighty. I'm quittin' the Army to settle down with you and the first thing you do is send me off for a honeymoon with 500 cows.
Who said I was goin'?
You'll go.
Yes, I'll go. Because a man in love with a woman don't have his right mind.
I'll get this off my chest...
Now, if I don't start seeing my money, I'm going to shoot.
There will be no killin' in my place.
Since when, since this morning? Alright, put that money on the table or get ready to feel lead.

Ward, you've got an idea you run this town, so I'll set you right about one thing. I've got my livestock and a pie business to take care of. That don't leave me much time for chasin' thieves! Keep your men away from my place or I'll double-load this gun and blow a whole in you that they could drive a team of mules through.
I need some needles and another sack of flour for those dull-darn pies.
Those dull-darn pies are makin' you a good livin'!
There are better ways than that to get ahead. How much are your needles?
A quarter a piece.
Twenty-five cents! Why, you ole Scotchman! What do you have to do? Find them in a haystack?
I don't like him.
How do you know? You never met him before.
I've got a good nose.
He happens to be something you'll never be - a gentleman.
He happens to be a sweet lookin' dude and a woman that would pay any heed to him ought to have her her head looked into!
Oh, I see. In other words you think I'm just plumb crazy!
I started this trouble for you, started by talking like a darned old woman.
Oh, straighten up. You're supposed to be the man around here.
Not any more.
Doggone it, Peter. If this is what its like to be in love, I'm glad I'm only going to love but once.
